problem_text:
19.98. A connected graph Σ is a symmetrical extension of a graph Γ by a graph ∆if there exist a vertex-transitive group G of automorphisms of Σ and an imprimitivity system σ of G on the set of vertices of Σ such that the quotient graph Σ/σ is isomorphic to Γ and blocks of σ generate in Σ subgraphs isomorphic to ∆.
(a) Let Γ be a locally finite Cayley graph of a finitely presented group, and ∆ a finite graph. Are there only finitely many symmetrical extensions of Γ by ∆?
(b) Let Γ be a locally finite graph which has the property of k-contractibility for some positive integer k (see the definition in (V. I. Trofimov, Proc. Steklov Inst. Math., 279, suppl. 1 (2012), 107–112); note that any Γ from (a) is such a graph) and let ∆be a finite graph. Are there only finitely many symmetrical extensions of Γ by ∆?
V. I. Trofimov
answer:
(a) No, not always, as follows from the construction in the proof of Theorem H in (M. de la Salle, R. Tessera, J. Topology, 12 (2019), 705–743).
(b) No, not always as follows from the construction in the proof of Theorem H in (M. de la Salle, R. Tessera, J. Topology, 12 (2019), 705–743).
